canvases.label: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, f.2, p.1

metadata.value: Page 1 of 5. An original letter in Rachel Erskine’s hand, dated St Kilda, January 20th 1738. The letter recounts her brutal abduction and subsequent captivity on the island and is addressed to Charles Erskine of Tinwald. The ink is faint and the four folio pages are weak where they have been folded. Laing observes that the letter was “evidently written at different intervals, and the smaller size of the letters near the end was occasioned by the necessity of completing it on a single sheet of paper”. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Charles Erskine in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.

canvases.label: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, Selection of letters

metadata.value: The Lady Grange papers include letters that describe, in her own hand, the plight of Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange (1679-1745). Lady Grange was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754), out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Lord Advocate Charles Erskine in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745. The collection also includes other letters and papers related to Lady Grange, such as a letter of separation from Lady Grange to Lord Grange, transcriptions of Lady Grange's letters, and an article written by David Laing on the letters.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Letter of Separation, 1730, f.1, p.1

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2.An original letter to James Erskine of Grange from his wife, Rachel Erskine, Lady Grange, setting out an offer of terms for their marriage separation. The letter sheet has also been preserved, and it bears the date 27 July 1730. The letter sheet also indicates that it was received by the solicitor on 28 July 1739. Lady Grange asks for a hundred pound Stirling per year, as well as some household effects, from Lord Grange. If these needs are met, she says that she will leave Lord Grange alone. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.

canvases.label: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, f.3, p.1

metadata.value: Page 1 of 4. An undated and uncredited handwritten transcription of a letter originally written by Lady Grange. The original letter is dated St Kilda, January 20th 1738. It recounts Lady Grange’s brutal abduction and subsequent captivity on the island and is addressed to Charles Erskine of Tinwald. The transcription is written on blue paper. Gaps are left where the transcriber was uncertain of Lady Grange’s writing. Although paragraph structure has been maintained, features such as the decreasing size of Lady Grange’s writing as she worked to fit her statement onto her remaining pages, are not transcribed. At the top of the first page and the bottom of the last page on the transcription, handwritten notes have been written in a second hand. The first note references the original Lady Grange letter and the second note records the information that appeared on the letter sheet, which was not transcribed by the original transcriber. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. canvases.label: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, f.4, p.1

metadata.value: Page 1 of 11. An undated and uncredited handwritten transcription of Lady Grange’s account of her brutal treatment during her kidnapping from Edinburgh and subsequent exile on St Kilda. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Charles Erskine in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745. Differing slightly from the 1738 letter addressed to Charles Erskine, this account includes descriptions of her efforts to get letters off the island and names a reverend who tried to help her and who felt under threat for doing so. The reverend’s name appears in the transcription, but has been subsequently blacked out with ink. The transcription is one of several copies said to exist of this account and Laing notes that the original account is generally thought to be dated around 1741. This proliferation of copies could be due to Lady Grange’s own instructions in the account, which ask that whoever receives the letter “may cause to write it over in a fair hand & show it to all my friends”. This particular transcription is missing pages 5 and 6 (as noted in Dr. Carlyle’s hand on the bottom of page 4). Included in the Laing collection, however, is an 1850 transcription of the missing pages copied down from a printing of Lady Grange’s account that appeared in “Edinburgh Magazine and Literary Miscellany, being a New Series of the Scots Magazine for November 1817, Is. 333”. The 1850 transcriber notes that “the copy printed is not precisely the same as this one, but the differences seem immaterial. They are certainly however not copies of each other. And it is probable that this copy, had been forwarded by Lady Grange’s directions to the Revd William Carlyle Minister of Prestonpans, in which Parish she + her husband had so long resided – and who was the father of Dr. Carlyle [of Inveresk, d. 1805], in whose repositories this imperfect copy was found.” The paper of the transcription is aged and weakened along the folds. Some pages have been reinforced since being archived.
metadata.label: Description

canvases.label: Letter to Charles Erskine, Lord Advocate Respecting Lady Grange, 1740, f.5, p.1

metadata.value: Letter to Charles Erskine, Lord Advocate Respecting Lady Grange, 1740
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 1 of 2. A letter from Mr. Hope of Rankeillor addressed to "The Right Honorable Charles Erskine Esq, His Majesties Advocate" and dated 13 December 1740. Hope explains that he has received a letter from Lady Grange "of an old date" describing her plight. Hope is appalled at the treatment Lady Grange has had to bear, and is writing Erskine to implore him to help. Hope states his intention to call on Erskine the next day. The letter is written on both sides of the paper, and is considerably worn. The same paper has also been used as a letter sheet and the red wax seal is still largely intact on the paper. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.

metadata.value: Page 1 of 4. An undated and uncredited transcription of an original letter from Mr. Hope of Rankeillor addressed to "The Right Honorable Charles Erskine Esq, His Majesties Advocate". Hope's original letter has also been archived and digitised in the Laing collection (La.II.201 f.5). This transcription is well preserved and extends over four pages. metadata.value: Page 1 of 10. A hand-annotated, copy-edited article entitled “Mrs. Erskine, Lady Grange, in the Island of St Kilda”. The article was written by David Laing for the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in the journal “Proceedings of the Society, June 8, 1874” and it provides context for three sets of documents that Laing had acquired relating to Lady Grange. The hand annotations have been made by Laing and indicate changes and updates that he wished to make to the article. A revised version of the article adopting, among others, the changes that Laing has indicated throughout this document was published by Laing in November 1876 under the title “An Episode in the Life of Rachel Erskine, Lady Grange. Detailed by Herself in a Letter from St Kilda, January 20, 1738, And Other Original Papers” (a pdf of this article is available via http://archaeologydataservice.ac.uk/). All three documents discussed in the article are held in the Laing Collection and have been digitized (I. Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, La.II.201, f.2; II. Letter to Charles Erskine, Lord Advocate Respecting Lady Grange, 1740, La.II.201, f.5; III. Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, La.II.201, f.4). A fourth letter written by Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat, discussed only in the 1876 version of Laing’s article, has also been digitized (Letter to Thomas Fraser from Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat, La.II.201, f.7). Laing’s 1874 article includes a plate depicting a facsimile copy of Lady Grange’s handwriting, taken from her 1738 letter. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Charles Erskine, Lord Advocate in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.

canvases.label: Letter to Thomas Fraser from Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat, f.7, p.1

metadata.value: Letter to Thomas Fraser from Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Page 1 of 7. A letter written by Simon Fraser, Lord Lovat in Beaufort on 16 September 1732 to his cousin, Mr. Thomas Fraser in Edinburgh. Among other things, Lord Lovat was a Jacobite convicted of treason against the crown and beheaded in 1747. He was also a friend to Lord Grange and one of the people most vehemently blamed by Lady Grange for her 1732 abduction and imprisonment. In this letter, Lord Lovat discusses two rumours circulating about him. The first is regarding a woman who has sworn a child against him, which he denies. The second is regarding suspicions around Lord Lovat’s role in Lady Grange’s disappearance. He denies any involvement and states that he wishes “that devil” would “never be seen again”. Lord Lovat also states that he would advise Mr. Thomas Hope of Rankeillor, who supports Lady Grange, not to “meddle with me, for the moment that I can prove that he attacts [sic] my character and reputation by any calumnie I’l [sic] certainly pursue him for Scandalum Magnatum”. The letter is quite worn and some pieces from the letter’s pages have been torn away. Patching has been performed in some places to preserve the paper. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. This plot was designed by her husband, James Erskine, Lord Grange, (1679-1754) out of fear that Lady Grange would expose him as a Jacobite. News of her plight began to be known when letters were smuggled off St Kilda in 1738, taking two years to reach Charles Erskine, Lord Advocate in Edinburgh in 1740. By this time, she had spent nearly nine years on the island in very poor living conditions. Although a rescue attempt was arranged, she was again kidnapped before this help could reach her. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.

canvases.label: Letters from Lady Grange, St. Kilda, 1738, f.2, p.5

metadata.value: Page 5 of 5. An original letter in Rachel Erskine’s hand, dated St Kilda, January 20th 1738. The letter recounts her brutal abduction and subsequent captivity on the island and is addressed to Charles Erskine of Tinwald. The ink is faint and the four folio pages are weak where they have been folded. Laing observes that the letter was “evidently written at different intervals, and the smaller size of the letters near the end was occasioned by the necessity of completing it on a single sheet of paper”. Rachel Erskine (née Chiesley), Lady Grange, (1679-1745) was forcibly kidnapped and exiled to the isle of St Kilda in 1732. After 1740, she was moved to various locations in the islands, leading to her eventual arrival in Skye in 1742. She died unrescued on Skye in 1745.
